name: Keyhole Surgery
description:
New ideas:

  • Same Old Thing -> Levy AR Lab Access to keep those Knights coming
  • Account Siphon -> Lawyer Up or John Masanori -> Lawyer Up to help with the card draw
  • e3 Feedback Implants does 3 things: beats Janus, beats Stronger Together, gets me discounts on Knights usage

Rest is basically the same as before. I parted with a third copy of Account Siphon - you can't have everything I guess. Went a little lighter on caissa stuff to make room for new cards and speed up the setup. Also 3 Mimics this time to maximize early aggresion (Neural Katana and Fenris are not the best ICE to facecheck).

I think Levy AR Lab Access is the way to go in order to recur Knights when they run out, as it does many more things at the same time. I still left a single Pawn as its purpose is dual - caissa recurrency and Power Shutdown protection.

Tried tag-me with Reina and failed (got murdered by Closed Accounts several times), thus Lawyer Ups went in.

name: Big Mac v0.2
description:
A different take of the previous version: The Toolbox instead of Grimoire, and 2 Sharpshooters have been added.

The influence from Grimoire has been spent in a single Vamp and in the upgrade (?) of Crescentus to Emergency Shutdown.

This deck can manage Power Shutdown very well thanks to Clone Chips, and the single tutorable Net Shield helps against the Jinteki PE "15 agendas" decks.

name: Weyland GRNDL Bad Pub Suicide
Zero Kelvin (Deep Ice Barrier)
description:
Casual, easy to play turtle deck.

Ices are chosen to counter most common icebreakers. Except Datapike every ice is or can be advanced over magic 3 strength, shutting down Mimic, Yog and make it expensive for Crypsis, Darwin to get through. If oponnent plays Datasuckers, Darwin or Knights instead of adding strength Corp can add subroutines on Tyrant or Swarm. Ice Walls, Datapike, Shadows, RSVP and Oversight AI are there to stop/tax Runner early on. Isabel McGuire and Levy University help optimize defense later on. Amazon Industrial Zone and Dedicated Server help get expensive ices in.

Any feedback appreciated.

name: Credit Denial v0.1
description:
Haven't really played in ages, so this is my first attempt at deckbuilding since before C&C.

The idea is to use Reina's ability, along with Xanadu, to keep the cost of rezzing ICE high.

To keep the corporation's credits too low to do anything, we have Account Siphon and Vamp. Lawyer Up gives a cost-efficient way to remove the tags that this will result in.

In the event that ice is rezzed, we have parasites to kill it and a multitude of AI-breakers to force our way through.

To ensure we keep our own cash high enough, we have a large number of income options. Liberated Accounts and Daily Casts provide the backbone, with Sure Gamble to help the deck set up in the early game. Scheherazade and Gorman drip I am more uncertain of. The idea behind including Scheherazade should be clear, I have a large number of Caissa programs, though this may be the first thing that needs changing in later versions of the deck. I felt that the deck may force the Corp into many "basic" actions to try and get going, hence the Gorman Drip.

In the case the Corp gets a significant amount of credits, we can use Running Interference and Rook to increase the rez costs even higher.

Finally, we have Deja Vu to recur any Caissa lost to trashing and parasites.

Criticism would be greatly appreciated!

name: Noise's keyhole
description: So the idea here is grab virus and install them and then once a turn get in on RD and toss a card increasing either the agenda density in archives OR trashing jackson Howard

name: Haas rush
description: Focused on Hass's click system.Tried to use Haas Arcology AI but I found out it doesn't save your time really.Efficiency Committee is important because of its link with Melange Mining Corp and Shipment From San San.Mandatory Upgrades is great but has more risk,once scored is gonna greatly accelerate your pace.But the center severs maybe weak.So I used Hudson1.0 and Swordsman to protect.But maybe they are still weak.Fenris is gonna hurt if you just run into it. Need adjustment.I'll appreciate if you offer advice!

name: HB Big Ice (WESU)
description: My current corp deck.

name: Street Chess (WESU)
description: Version I've been testing

name: RP: Sundew OP
Rise of the Biroids
description: Going for a taxing all biroid deck. All econ coming from operations and hopefully getting my big biroids out for free.

name: ThisONEHB.o8d
description: HB with good econ, fast advance, and a couple snares.

name: Red Queen's Master Key
Advanced Biotics
description:
Advanced Biotics aspires to make the runner very uncertain if that double-advanced card behind the ICE fort is an agenda, a trap, or a total waste of their time.

Fun notes: Haas Arcology is used as a safe-ish way of scoring Vitruvius out of hand, or anything you might use that extra click for. Double-advanced Trap + Simone = Free advancing of Hadrians/Ice Walls until you care to replace the trap or the runner risks it. Activating and trashing Thomas Haas mid-run is a cathartic experience. Matrix Analyzer + Thomas Haas = makeshift popup window. Shipments + Thomas Haas = clutch econ.

Sad notes: Weak econ. Susceptible to emergency shutdowns etc due to large ice. Susceptible to shutdown-FAO combo on advanced Hadrians.

name: NBN Fast Advance
NBN 3/2
description: Built around 3/2s and 3/1s, SanSan, and Operations based credit gen. Smaller deck size identity chosen to promote consistency.

name: Jinteki Trash and Tax
description: Ice choices emphasize making it so they can't simply run on archives or something and just allow the run to end to bypass RP's text. Emphasis on trashing programs as well.

name: HB Ice Tricks
description: All about rezzing fat ice cheaply. Use Jackson Howard to draw up past hand size, dump agendas, and shuffle them back if you aren't ready to protect them.

name: Weyland Iceless "Should I Stay or Should I Go"
description: This is an iceless deck intended to punish the runner whether they decide to run or not, with the primary win condition of flatlining the runner, and an alternate win condition of scoring agendas. The deck is built to have an economic advantage over the runner, primarily through transaction operations and secondarily through drip economy installed on remote servers. Your pile of creds and exposed HQ may tempt a runner to Account Siphon you, and they may leave themselves tagged and exposed to a Scorched Earth. The runner will also be forced to eat up creds and clicks trashing your drip economy, slowing his own hardware and program installs, which you should be picking off with Grid Overload and Power Shutdown (especially Plascrete Carapace). As you trash cards with Power Shutdown, use Jackson Howard to funnel your trashed Snares! and any agendas you're not ready to score or have scored back into R&D, at which time you should be consolidating your Punitive Counterstrikes and Scorched Earths into HQ. Use Interns to recur your drip economy and Cerebral Overwriters. In the meantime, advance a Cerebral Overwriter to see if they access it blindly. Or start advancing one of the synergistic agendas if you are ready to Punitive Counterstrike if the Runner decides to score it. Who knows, you might even be able to score an agenda if they've already been hit by a Cerebral Overwriter and are hesitant to continue running. If you can score an agenda, it'll make your end-game that much easier, as they amplify meat damage or allow you to search for that last card you need. Eventually, as R&D dwindles, it should be thick with agendas and Snare!s, but you should have the pieces in your hand to flatline the runner when (s)he encounters them. This is a very easy deck to drive considering there are hard and fast rules for what you should do with most of the pieces once you draw them. The only subtleties may be managing how many agendas you wish to leave in archives at one time and whether or not you want to try and advance a Cerebral Overwriter or an agenda. NOTE: Some substitutions for Cerebral Overwriter might be SEA Source or Shock! (among others) depending on your meta.

name: Weyland Slow Roll
description: Build up a giant mound of credits, try and keep at least 10 in reserve for Corporate War/Restructure. Never draw extra cards, when you have nothing else to do keep advancing ice. Wall up a single remote server for agendas. Hopefully you don't need to much protection for HQ, as you'll be playing and scoring agendas once you draw into them. Corporate Troubleshooter for forcing through Grim or buying a turn to finish an agenda up. Matrix Analyzer for free advances and tags to trash resources and for Closed Accounts. (Closed Accounts is also a local meta call, a lot of the local playing field runs Account Siphons in multiples.)

name: Andromeda runs lean
description: Looking for feedback. Lean deck focusing on cheap runs without being power shut down on my suckers

name: Criminal Notoriety.
description: Run wherever it suits you. Make 'em derez ice.

name: Prof
Ice Tax and Kill
description: Make ice expensive. Kill ice with Parasites and Activation orders. ???. Profit.

name: Sun Drops on Glaciers
description: Protect fantastic assets behind huge layers of brutal ice. Slowly score out Agendas and tire out the Runner.

name: Chess Recursion
description: A different chess deck, this one with more recurssion since most of my caissa are burned down all the time. Scheherazade makes almost everything cheaper, and the 2 pawn combo is awesome. MU may become a problem, so you need to use what you really need at the time.

name: NBN 3/2
description: SanSan and 3 cost agendas.

name: Big Bad Ice
description: Big ice means big problems

name: Chaos Theories
description: CT with no console, just her built in memory. Lightweight rig with some one-shot options.
